title: Circuit with two resistors and inductor

content.question: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. The circuit shown above consists of an ideal battery, two resistors, an inductor, and a switch. The switch is initially open. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the switch is closed. (a) i. Calculate the current in resistor <math alttext="R sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> immediately after the switch is closed. ii. Calculate the potential difference across the inductor immediately after the switch is closed. iii. On the axes below, sketch the potential difference <math alttext="delta V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> across the inductor as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. The circuit shown above consists of an ideal battery, two resistors, an inductor, and a switch. The switch is initially open. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the switch is closed. (a) i. Calculate the current in resistor <math alttext="R sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> immediately after the switch is closed. ii. Calculate the potential difference across the inductor immediately after the switch is closed. iii. On the axes below, sketch the potential difference <math alttext="delta V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> across the inductor as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) After a long time, the switch is now opened.i. Calculate the current in resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> immediately after the switch is opened.ii. Is the current up through <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, down through <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, or zero?_____ Up through <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> _____ Down through <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> _____ Zero

(c) Write, but do NOT solve, the differential equation for the current <math alttext="I of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> through the inductor after the switch is opened.

(d) Using integral calculus, derive an equation to show that the equation of the current as a function of time is <math alttext="I of t equals, I sub 0, end sub, times, e raised to the fraction negative t over tau, power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="tau equals, the fraction, L over R sub 2, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (e) The procedure is repeated, with the switch closed for a long time and then opened. Points <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are indicated in the circuit diagram, as shown.

i. Resistors of different resistances <math alttext="R sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are placed at position <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The switch is closed for a long time and then opened. The following two measurements are made for each resistor: the maximum current <math alttext="I sub MAX A, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>MAX-A</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the inductor immediately after the switch is opened and the time <math alttext="T sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> it takes the current in the inductor to reach <math alttext="67%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>67</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of its initial value after the switch is opened. On the axes below, sketch graphs of <math alttext="I sub MAX A, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>MAX-A</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="T sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> as functions of <math alttext="R sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

ii. Resistors of different resistances <math alttext="R sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are now placed at position <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The switch is closed for a long time and then opened. The following two measurements are made for each resistor: the maximum current <math alttext="I sub MAX B, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>MAX-B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the inductor immediately after the switch is opened and the time <math alttext="T sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> it takes the current in the inductor to reach <math alttext="67%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>67</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of its initial value after the switch is opened. On the axes below, sketch graphs of <math alttext="I sub MAX B, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>MAX-B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="T sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> as functions of <math alttext="R sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 13.5: Circuits with Resistors and Inductors (LR Circuits)

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
